Honestly idk where to even start with this one. I wanna love this game so bad, like 10/10 love it, but Capcom is making it SO hard right now.

First off, the actual game? Absolute fire. The combat is hands down the best it's ever been. They added this "Focus Mode" thing that lets you target wounds and it feels so crunchy when you hit those weak spots. The new weapons movesets are sick, and being able to switch weapons on the fly with the Seikret (the bird mount thing) is a game changer. The world itself is seamless now, no loading screens between zones, and the monsters actually feel like they live there. When it works, it‚Äôs easily the most immersive MH game ever. The monster designs are terrifying in a good way.

BUT. And this is a massive BUT.

The performance is straight garbage. I‚Äôm not even joking. I‚Äôm running a decent rig (RTX 30 series) and this game chugs like it‚Äôs running on a toaster. The optimization is nonexistent. You walk into a busy area or get some weather effects and your frames just tank. It‚Äôs not just the FPS either, the textures are weirdly blurry? Like sometimes the ground looks like PS3 graphics until it decides to pop in five seconds later.

It‚Äôs frustrating because the core gameplay loop is addictive as hell, but then you get hit with a stutter right in the middle of a combo and you wanna throw your controller. It feels like they focused 100% on gameplay and 0% on making sure it actually runs on normal PCs.

Verdict:
If you have a NASA supercomputer, get it. You‚Äôll have a blast.
If you have a normal PC? Maybe wait for a few patches. The game is incredible underneath the lag, but right now the performance is barely acceptable. Capcom needs to fix this ASAP cause it's ruining a masterpiece.

After much consideration, I can't help but recommend this game despite my issues with... many things. I've been playing since 4U and I cannot bear to "hate" a MonHun game. Without getting too far into the critique, do not buy this at full price! Especially in the current state, and because you can't guarantee you will like the endgame loops, it's not worth spening 70‚Ç¨ on this game. Get a key, get it on sale, and play with friends. The endgame here is truly the meat and potatoes of Wilds, including a HR100 grind that is supposedly becoming easier in TU4 with an event quest.

The soundtrack, the combat (with a new wound mechanic) and the monster designs and areas are incredible, the performance issues almost make sense when you see the beautiful landscapes you commit mass genocide in. The monster designs range from a monster with a face AND tail that look like a drill to a railgun and the most unique ones of all, big squids that WILL use all of their tentacles fully. The compositions for this game are exactly what I want from a MonHun soundtrrack, true heroes are the Jin Dahaad and of course the Rey Dau theme, but the main menu of all things has stuck with me as well. The ecology, the story, the DAMN SEIKRET BABIES. I love so much on display here. I'm glad that 6th gen looks this good, we've come a long way as a series.

The story mode! It's... really short for a game of this price. I really like the characters having names, personalities and motivations in this one. The fact your handler FOLLOWS you onto a HUNT? God, is that what we were supposed to be seeing the whole time? The Seikret mechanic surely makes this much easier to implement, but every character is so... involved in this world. Nata as a central character you can periodically check up on optionally adds some tonal depth and his arc of revenge to compasion towards arkveld is truly sad when you eventually have to put it down. At least it would be sad, if Alma didn't have a kill phrase implanted in my brain that makes me feel like a hitman towards my target monster (I'm joking of course, but I do feel awesome when she says it). This is by far the best monster hunter in terms of characters, bringing back many themes and people from MH4U and its own original ones, joining you on hunts for dialogue before you start fighting that big spider. Your hunter talks, by the way.
Most well known is the final boss of this game, Zoh Shia, which acts as an interpretation of the equal dragon weapon. If you don't know that concept, look it up. Seriously. This may or may not be the case but the fact the devs took that concept, made it even cooler and then made it the most awesome fight in this game (arguably) is a surprise to me.

I could go on about my absolute love for the game, talk about the endgame grind of talismans and artian weapons (I'm still waiting for craftable decorations, capcom.), I didn't even mention focus mode or the crossover... I think I would rather mention some negatives. The multiplayer is a little odd, you need to join link parties and, while an option, environment links are as fragile as a nerscylla hatchling. This pales in comparison to the performance. Please fix, capcom. This game has some serious potential to have the impact world had, bringing in a whole new generation of players to this beast of a series, but that one snag... the performance. It held even me personally back until recently where I upgraded to a 4060 and I can run the game fine. I did go into the files and edited a lot of visuals though, the windward plains still lagged me. 

I think the "difficulty" discussion is a little overdone. It's on the easier side, sure, but WOW this game can hit you between the legs just as much as one thinks back on their first MonHun game kicking them. Chances are you are not a Sixer but rather a Fiver who plays this game, comes from having learned mechanincs in World/Iceborne, and blasting monsters with the wounds and your main weapon you already found. I have a Fiver friend who I play with and, while they played all the way to Fatalis in World, much prefers Wilds *because* of the faster hunts. And this is not to say that even AT Uth Duna is fast, those take your usual 20-25 minutes. Even normal Tempered hunts (not even double ones) can take 20-30 minutes, at least for us two. If you want some difficulty you truly do need to get further into the game, but once you hit a 9-5 Star Tempered Gore Magala you will SCREAM and CRY.

This may not be everyone's cup of tea, but to those true diehard MonHun fans who want difficulty: Try savage Omega Planetes, have yourself a 9-5 Tempered Seregios hunt. It's hard! and with AT monsters and Gogmazios on the horizon I only see the endgame getting spicier. Let the early game be easy, I'd much rather blast through La La Barina in 5 minutes and genuinely struggle on High Rank Zoh Shia.

This game suffers from performance issues and a community that cannot decide what difficulty it wants. I have VERY high hopes for this game and its eventual DLC, and I will continue to support this series into any generation as long as it's not completely terrible. This can become the 6th-Gen game we all wanted, and I hope the team of talented individuals realizes this reality! Can't wait for TU4.

I've been playing this series since Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate and have played every monster hunter that released after 4U. I absolutely adore and love this series, its my favorite. However, I do have my gripes with it. Throughout my journey this series took a noticable shift with the gameplay and other details, many are positives, there are however also negatives. 

Starting with the core gameplay and the hunts: They're great. Despite some people swearing that the gameplay isn't. I personally don't have many issues with it. My only dislike is the new focus mode and other minor changes that I will get to. 
Disclaimer: I have ONLY played hammer as of now (and I plan to ONLY play hammer) so I can not talk about weapons that heavily rely on wounds to go into different modes or to fully use their moveset (eg. Charge Blade). 
The additions of wounds are great, they give a good feeling when used and open up opportunites to punish the monster or to reap your rewards when you successfully damage a monsters part more than enough times.
I do however dislike the fact how much mobility focus mode gives you as a hunter. The fact that you gain more reach with your weapon while holding down the button to activate focus mode is ridiculous. As well as how good your hunter is able to turn around attacking while holding down the focus mode. 
While I do not dislike the fact that our hunter gets stronger, I do dislike that fact that the monsters don't. Im unsure if its because I know my way around this game and some monsters-moveset after years of experience with this franchise, but I honestly fail to see if Capcom ever designs monsters around our hunter and our possibilites with our weapons and environment. As of now, the only difficul fights have been monsters where their damage have been sky-high (Tempered, arch tempered) and Omega (Which is a very fun hunt, but the design is sadly from Final Fantasy).

Another point are the monster designs. They're phenomenal. Stunning even. Weapon designs are also absolutely amazing. They fit right in and are a treat to fight against and use. BUT, as a hammer main.....why can you NOT break the head of Rathian and Rathalos? Seriously? It has been a real head scratcher for me since I first fought them in this addition. Is it because they don't want us the break the "beautiful" faces of their flagships? Is the reason really that silly? Im furious about this change.

Another great gripe I have is the whole Gravios hunt. Coming from 4 Ultimate, he was never my favorite (don't remind Capcom that black gravios exists). But he never felt...lazy...in a sense, unlike here. 2 Things I want to point out. He has a very basic design. Big rock with flesh under. But this design opened up many opportunites for the team in 4U, and by god they took them. Mounting him in 4U was fun because you could mount him on two places, the back and his chest with different animations. In this game its only the back, which is disappointing but Im not as heartbroken about it as the other change. His roar. They took a bear mp3. and made it his roar..... Im jawdropped. His original roar is still in Wilds but sadly they didn't make it his only roar, so you sometimes get thrown out of the immersion when the mp3 plays. 
Why make it that way? You have the blueprints already there. Seregios (My favorite monster god bless him) also got a more Falcon-esque cry which you can sometimes hear. His cry isn't a bad change, its nice but the bad change is definitely the change they gave Gravios, they must hate him.

Rewards are not as rare to come by like in older games which is very nice, now that I have less time to play due to busy days it's nice to ask friends if they have investigations with the items I need. 
This nice change is however instantly thrown away and stomped on by Artians weapons. Basically the gacha and grinding mechanism they have in almost every game for some gog-foresaken reason (Word/Iceborne decos and guiding lands, SunRise talismans and and augments). They're a nightmare to grind if you want to best possible weapons since you can't choose which augments you get on your weapon (Safi-weapons were better in this regard and design wise) and you have to destory the weapon if you don't get the right augments (you get back the upgrade materials you use for the augments, thats very kind). The worst thing about Artian weapons is sadly the upcoming Gogmazios. Unless they give us a way to upgrade monster-part-weapons, I fail to see why you should even use them since Gogmazios will upgrade your Artian weapons EVEN FURTHER, they will become the best weapons you can get (if you're lucky at the slot machine) and nothing will even compete against them. This however is pure speculation.

Lets get into the world of Wilds. Im not commenting on the story, Im only saying that Monster Hunter isn't a story game and they shouldn't push it to be one. This game further enhances my opinion.

Characters in Wilds are good, I like them a lot. Im super happy to see the Ace-Lancer and Little Miss Forge back, here's me hoping that we get to see the rest of the Aces or other characters from 4U when Gogmazios releases! 
Overall I do not dislike the things that we have on this topic, what I dislike are the things that are missing.
You're forced to listen to languages, there isn't the option to let the cast speak the "Monster Hunter language" like in World/Iceborne, thank gog that we're able to let our Palico speak in only meows (Hopefully they won't take this away from us in future games).
Speaking of cats, there aren't Palicos/Felynes cooking for you in this game. The villagers and your hunter cook the meals.

Perfomance wise I can not complain, I don't have the best or the worst system but the game runs, even tho it doesn't have the best graphics and framerate, its playable (we apparently reached the point where good enough is acceptable). They made a good job optimizing the mess they created, it was almost unplayable when I played the demo-version of this game.
I am a bit disappointed in the art-design choices of this game however. Monster Hunter for me was always a very colorful game. Even darker places like castle Schrade or Dundorma had a nice color palette in previous games. Iceborne was gorgeous and looks (and runs) way better than Wilds. Wilds however....Im disappointed. It looks very monotone and grey. Areas don't stand out since every area of a map looks almost the same.
Music is phenomenal like usual, great job on this one.

Even tho this review has been focusing on the negatives, Im still giving this game a good review. Its a great game, its fun, I don't regret buying this game and I will maybe buy the expansion. 
I am however very sad that Monster Hunter has lost so much of its soul and things that made me personally fall in love with it.
I hope they change their ways, but from the way things are and how much money they made with the game already [(and the in-game mico-transactions which are purely cosmetics) (Im also part of the problem for supporting Capcoms greed, Im sorry)]  I don't see a light at the end of the tunnel.

This is a very backhanded recommendation from me.

There's definitely been a lot of buzz around the negativity surrounding Wilds since its release. Personally, I think there were a number of challenges the game faced at release that really didn't do it any favors.

Among the most notable criticisms:

1.) PERFORMANCE AND OPTIMIZATION ON PC
2.) Lack of content, especially when it comes to the end-game
3.) Anemic gameplay outside of the combat, which was also criticized as too easy

I believe that Capcom has done much to try to "make it right" and improve.

Since release, Capcom has continued to flesh out content:

--More Monsters
--The Grand Hub
--Three whole Festivals with accompanying armor and weapons
--Dozens of Event Quests
--Challenge Quests
--Talismans
--Harder Monsters
--Our first Crossover Collaboration, presenting the hardest challenge in Wilds to date

When we compare base-game to base-game, Wilds has already exceeded World in terms of amount of content and upper-level difficulty.

And soon we'll have yet more content, bringing both Gogmazios as well as an expansion on upgrade mechanics for both Artian weapons and mid-grade armor sets. Title Update 4 also promises to deliver substantial stability and performance optimizations, where we will ultimately exceed the content provided in Monster Hunter World's base game by a substantial margine.

The game has had its issues, but I really do respect a passionate team of creatives who have done a lot to strive to produce a quality product *and* be right by their fans. This is not an easy task.

Upsides:
- This is the most beginner friendly Monster Hunter game. All of the menus are also easily understandable and responsive (even though having like 5 submenus for everything is annoying at times).
- Good roster. Only a few boring monsters and 1 terrible (Congalala).
- Good environment, huge attention to detail. Iceshard Cliffs is the only area which I've found annoying to fight in
- The story is fine. Nothing groundbreaking but entertaining enough. The final boss of Low Rank ques line is very good. The kid character did not annoy me unlike some other players who foam at the mouth the moment his name is mentioned (I really do not get the problem).
- After 3 Title Updates the endgame is very solid and the difficulty is there. The "star" system is confusing at first but not that hard to understand, the difficulty progression is solid with 6, 7, 8 and 9 star monsters.

Downsides
- Of course, performance. Even people with good PCs still struggle with this game because the release was rushed so the optimisation is poor. There have been updates improving it a little but the game still struggles. The devs promised to improve the performance on December 16th with the release of Title Update 4, I hope it will actually be substantial (improving the performance of your game almost 1 year after release is kinda crazy not gonna lie)
- In my opinion, the game lacks artstyle. The previous games were a product of their time and that gave them a certain style, the way they look is memorable. In Wilds they just went with super realistic, I wish there was more to it than that. The monsters are gorgeous, perhaps the playable characters could've been more cartoon-y.
- The amount of handholding during the story gets tiring. Multiple missions where you gotta ride on your mount and you cannot stray from the path (your character won't let you), it's all mostly on walking speed. It wasn't the worst thing in the world and it was probably done to show off how much work they've done on the environment but it at some point you've just had enough.
- More of a late game issue but I wish Artian weapons weren't in the game until like Title Update 3. For most weapons, they are the best option so the Rarity 8 weapons you can make out of the hardest monsters in the game are mostly useless. Yeah, of course I could just not interact with the system, but it would be stupid to deny their advantage.
I love Monster Hunter, Hopefully the expansion is better.

It's not a BAD game, it's fun, but I have two main gripes with it
1. The optimization is near non-existent. The devs forgot that DLSS and Framegen were supposed to be a feature for those with weaker machines to make games playable, not a requirement to get good FPS on high end hardware.
2. Unlike MH Rise, where I feel like the content kept rolling in pretty quickly, this one is... well, it doesn't get that much in it over time. And what it gets are either bullshit quests (all the Arch Tempered monsters that their only gimmick is that they have more HP and hit like a 10-ton truck, even if you use a Lance and can normally block almost everything) or 1 new monster every few months.

I played this on PC with a Ryzen 7 5700X3D, 32 GB DDR4, and an RTX 5070 12 GB. After almost 400 hours, this is one of the strongest Monster Hunter entries to date, though it is held back by major technical issues.

Gameplay and Combat

The combat in Monster Hunter Wilds is a significant evolution for the series. Focus Mode and the new movesets feel fresh without losing the classic Monster Hunter identity I have known since the PS2 era. Compared to Rise, the combat is far more grounded, weighty, and satisfying. Compared to World, not much different but feel less weighty while more realistic and lot more satisfying.

I have used every weapon and while a few feel average, the overall weapon design is excellent. Monster movesets, especially with the new 9 star difficulty, are intense and punishing. One mistake can easily result in a one-hit faint.

The only real downgrade for me is the investigation system, which leans more toward Rise-style boss hunting. It lacks the deeper investigative structure that made World‚Äôs hunts feel more immersive.

World and Exploration

The open-zone design has strong potential but feels underutilized. The environments look great at broader perspective, but the game does not encourage exploration the same way World did. Performance issues also reduce the enjoyment of traveling through these large areas.

Environmental interaction is where Wilds shines. Weather, small wildlife, and monster behavior react dynamically and make the world feel alive. Compared to previous titles, this is a major improvement, though the poor performance often overshadows it.

Story and Presentation

The story is more narrative-driven and gives your character a clearer role rather than being just an assistant. It is engaging but noticeably short. Progression feels much faster than World, which forced players to explore, investigate, and uncover clues before advancing.

The voice acting, cutscenes, and returning characters are excellent. Longtime fans will appreciate the comeback hunters far more than newcomers. Some specific scenes hit very hard emotionally, especially for veteran players.

Performance

This is the biggest issue with the game. Optimization on PC is weak. With my system, I run mixed High to Ultra settings with High RT at 1440p using DLSS Quality and no Frame Generation. I can maintain around 60 to 80 FPS, but drops into the mid-40s still happen.

There are also noticeable texture streaming problems. After loading into a zone, some textures will appear low-resolution or low-poly for a few seconds before the higher resolution versions load in. Texture pop-in is fairly common, especially when moving quickly between areas or after cutscenes. For a game of this scale, these streaming issues are distracting and make the presentation feel inconsistent.

A game with this visual quality should not be this demanding. PC optimization clearly needs improvement.

Title Update 4 (December 16, 2025) is supposedly bringing major performance improvements. If that update delivers, it will help significantly.

Graphics and Sound

Graphically, the game looks good but not exceptional for its generation. The visuals do not justify the heavy performance cost. At 4K60 the game looks excellent tho, though some textures appear pixelated.

Sound design is outstanding. Battle themes, village and base themes, and environmental ambience are all high quality and add a lot to the overall experience. The soundtrack work for returning monsters and several newcomers stands out in particular. Some of these themes hit extremely hard in-game, especially with monsters like Rey Dau, Nu Udra, and the long-awaited return of Lagiacrus.

Overall Experience

When the game holds above 60 FPS, it feels incredible. As someone who has played the series since Monster Hunter 1 on PS2, Wilds feels like a blend of World and Rise that finally gets the best of both worlds. Unfortunately, poor PC optimization hinders what could have been a near-perfect experience.

Highly recommended for Monster Hunter fans who have capable hardware.

For newcomers or those with weaker systems, it may be better to wait for Title Update 4 or a sale.

Recommended system if you plan to buy now: something around a Ryzen 5 7600 or equivalent, a 9060XT 16 GB class GPU (or equivalent) or at least 5060 / 9060xt 8GB minimum, and 32 GB RAM with NVMe storage.

If performance improves in future updates, this will be an easy recommendation for nearly everyone.

I've been playing MH Wilds since the release in February and I think it's time to post a review after having +300 hours played. I have to admit this is the best game I've played in 2025, it's definitely my favorite release this year. I'd like to cover different aspects of what makes this game the wonderful game it is:

Story and Characters:
I've played previous releases of MH before since PSP era and MH games used to be simpler, however MH Wilds is different and it has the best and more complex storyline in a MH game ever, the story is beautifully written with great memorable characters and it has a meaningful message about the ecosystem and shows you that balance is important to preserve things, our Hunter protagonist feels really engaged with the story and the mission, and you can feel a real bond with the game characters, it feels completely seamless and it offers and immersive experience. The characters are the best ones for me in any MH game, they have their distinct personalities, great dialogues and expressions, I feel in love with these characters and enjoyed the story so much together with them, that it made me care for the world and the future of the characters.

Battle:
All the known and existing weapons from previous MH games are back, with expanded and updated functionality, each weapon offers a completely different gameplay and it's one of the reasons that makes this game so fun, because you can always experiment with new weapons and master your favorites, each hunt feels different depending on the weapon you choose. There's also a lot of QoL aspects that have been incorporated in this game to make the battle experience more enjoyable such as mount autopilot, customizable radial menu, customizable loadouts of items, armor and weapons, it's very detailed and interesting.

Monsters:
Each monster in this game has very unique attack patterns and gimmicks you have to learn to be able to master their hunts, it's extremely enjoyable to fight them and follow the learning curve to become better at fighting them, there's no repetitive attack patterns between monsters, all of them, even the initial ones feel completely unique and authentic. Some of them have their own battle music and locales where they spawn, it makes the world feel completely alive.

Other notable mechanics:
Game offers great additional functionality that makes it very enjoyable, there's cross play in multiplayer, so you can play with friends regardless if they are in console or PC, there's a hub where we have constant events, and even a bowling counter, the maps have different weathers and monsters and endemic life that spawn constantly, it's a changing beautiful world that always offers something to do, even when you are not hunting a particular monster. The armor customization is also amazing and super immersive, it offers a lot of grinding love, and unlimited customization in terms of skills you can equip, the combinations are so huge that a lot of hours can be put just on creating different armor combinations and testing them for results in your hunts. 

Music:
The music of the game is completely epic, there are so many nice songs, my favorite of all is the Ice cliffs battle song, Rey Dau and Mizutsune battle themes, some of these were existing songs that have been rearranged for this game, the soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, many of the songs use horn instruments which are perfectly fitting for the setting of this game, and it helps with the immersion during battles. The recent FF14 collab brought a new fight with great music as well. 

Performance:
I know there have been complaints about performance of this game, however I want to say that I've never had performance issues with MH Wilds, it has always run perfectly well since I started playing, not even crashes, while other games with less graphics have crashed on me, MH wilds hasn't and it always runs very well, even when using other apps at the same time such as Firefox and Whatsapp desktop App.  I play on PC but I'm not running the ultimate PC rig nor anything like that, I have a machine that has a few years already, it has Intel 12th gen processor and GPU is a RTX 4070, and the game runs completely flawless at full quality and FPS. 

So in summary, I want to say this is an amazing game, I highly recommend it, my favorite of this year, it brings joy and immersion, and if you have friends to play with even better, if not, there's always people online that you can hunt together with, making this a great multiplayer experience too.

Going into this game I was eagerly excited. How could hunting monsters be anything other than extraordinarily invigorating? How could one possibly fuck this up? I knew there were performance issues people complained about, but I was undaunted. I decided to support this franchise, one of the last that still sparks dopamine in me. Against common sense I bought the deluxe edition as a token of good faith to the dev team.

Performance issues for me were rare, so I assumed it was just people with outdated rigs trying to squeeze performance out of their decaying GPUs. My friend had issues with his semi-old setup barely hitting 30 fps despite tweaking his settings. I got 60 fps with my 4060 TI. I‚Äôm not a max graphics kind of guy, so it was good enough for me.

Where everything fell apart was in the core gameplay. I consider myself a seasoned hunter, not a speedrunner. So when I started killing monsters in five minutes flat, I thought something was wrong. I told myself it must be because it‚Äôs low rank. Surely high rank would ramp up the challenge. Right? Right?? No. It didn‚Äôt. What I found was a game on rails. Beautiful worlds, sure, but they mean nothing when your mount takes you directly to the monster every single time. I don‚Äôt even count travel time anymore because it‚Äôs automatic. The real fight starts when the laser pointer stops, and that‚Äôs about five minutes of empty motion. The fanbase calling this ‚Äúrewarding‚Äù or ‚Äúrespectful of my limited game time‚Äù absolutely baffles the fuck out of me.

I haven‚Äôt suddenly become a god-tier hunter overnight. The problem is the monsters hit like toddlers. There‚Äôs no fear, no tension, no need to respect them. You can play recklessly and win. The older games punished greed. One bad swing could send you back to camp, forcing you to think and adapt. Here, the monsters might as well have foam teeth. You can stun-lock them in half a dozen ways. You can play with your eyes closed. The game inflates everyone‚Äôs skill by making failure nearly impossible. And the fanbase cheers like cattle for being bottle-fed easy mode, insisting, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just low and high rank that‚Äôs easy, wait till G rank!‚Äù

I was so disappointed that I went back and replayed Rise, then World. Within an hour I realized how far the series has fallen. There‚Äôs no auto-find. My weapons have weight. I can‚Äôt greed attacks because I‚Äôll actually get punished. I got carted several times adjusting back from Wilds‚Äô hand-holding design and I laughed. The contrast was that stark. Rise reminded me what risk feels like. Wilds feels like a padded room where you‚Äôre not allowed to fail, not allowed to feel.

In Wilds you can hunt two monsters of any type and already have everything you need to craft a full armor set. That‚Äôs about five to seven minutes per hunt, tops. Ninety-eight percent of the game is you coasting half-awake, waiting for the credits to roll. Once you‚Äôve crafted your weapon, armor, and decorations, you‚Äôre done. There‚Äôs no drive left. God forbid the FOMO-afflicted crowd actually face something difficult. Finding the monster is automatic, fighting it is a formality, and gathering loot is guaranteed. Why stop there? In the next installment they might as well add an ‚Äúauto-hunt‚Äù feature, and the fanbase will probably call it ‚Äúa quality-of-life improvement.‚Äù

And yeah, I‚Äôve seen the noise about how there are no strong male characters, how the cast is full of girls and one brown kid who won‚Äôt stop whining. Sure, that‚Äôs annoying, but it‚Äôs not why this game fails. I don‚Äôt give a fuck about the story. I‚Äôm not here for politics or representation debates. I‚Äôm here to hunt monsters. I‚Äôm here to feel challenge, danger, and triumph.

Instead, what I got feels hollow. The gameplay loop is soulless. The fights have no tension, no grit, no weight. Every victory feels unearned. Every monster feels defanged. And the fanbase‚Äôs defense‚Äîthat ‚Äúa couple of late-game monsters are hard‚Äù‚Äîis the most damning thing of all. You‚Äôre telling me I need to mindlessly wade through hours of filler just to finally experience the ghost of what Monster Hunter used to be?

This isn‚Äôt evolution. It‚Äôs lobotomy. The spirit of Monster Hunter wasn‚Äôt just about the grind; it was about struggle, tension, and mastery. That‚Äôs gone. What‚Äôs left is an empty shell of a once-great series made safe for people who don‚Äôt actually like difficulty but still want to feel like they‚Äôve conquered something.

Monster Hunter Wilds doesn‚Äôt respect your time. It drains it. It flatlines your passion. It turns the hunt into a checklist and the player into a consumer. And the saddest part is that people will call this progress. I can't in good faith suggest this for anyone until they address the core gameplay loop...which won't be happening because they want to appeal to new hunters and not actual hunters.

I waited a long time before putting out a review of this game. Please understand that I've been with this series since 2007, so I have an attachment to it unlike any other game series I've immersed myself in. 

To get to the point; Capcom is ridiculous for putting this game out the way they did. This game clearly was supposed to release in 2026 but we sure needed to get the Japanese fiscal numbers looking nice before we close because shareholders run everything. 

This game is a mess, the CPU overhead is ridiculously high with how much the game both inefficiently handles rendering as well as a layer of denuvo running on top. Its been 8 months and they've yet to drop the denuvo despite the game's opening sales having carried Capcom so hard and now they've tapered off so much because it's obvious this game is incomplete (and I'm not talking content wise). 

If you have an 8GB VRAM gpu, do not buy this. This game is so imbalanced in its graphical processing that no matter what settings you change you'll experience the same abysmal frame rate and frame times as everyone else. The graphical processing crutches on needing upscaling and frame generation to achieve low standards like 1080p / 60fps - I have a top end GPU from 2020 that has handled modern day releases in 2025 at 1440p and worst case I cap at 60. This game? I'll be amazed if I can hold 60, even using upscalers or driver upscaling. It just won't. work. 

The only reason I have the playtime I have is because I'm attached to the series but I also have a desktop that can brute force most of these issues, but my 8GB 3070 laptop is a miserable time on this game. I can, at best, achieve 40~45fps. They've made many updates, and most of them are questionable of it they've done anything. 

The community has done their best to salvage what they can, reframework eases up some of the frame time issues, another tool was released that can let you decompress the textures in this game so that the texture streaming issue can be mitigated, but even with these the game is still unreliable. 

The biggest offense is this game crashes, so often. Of all the games I've bought from Japanese developers I cannot recall one that has crashed this often, to this degree. At least once a day this game crashes on me and it is downright infuriating to have been in a hunt for upwards of 15 minutes and nearing the goal only for it to get taken away as there is always an issue with Nvidia or an AMD driver with this game's compatibility. 

-

When you get past the downright awful performance, this is probably one of my top 3 favorite monster hunter games, and its a shame because the gameplay is fast, the monsters are fast, and its so obvious this game wants you in the field more than doing anything else at camp. Capcom has promised many times they will perform updates and fix this horrendous performance, they've at best taken steps but their efforts have brought the game from "this is terrible" to "this is playable, i guess." $70 premium price is a joke, MH is the only series I ever bothered preordering and it seems I have to learn the hard way. 

Capcom promises with the major title update in December that there will be greater CPU and GPU optimizations to the game as it is (assumedly based on past game trends) their last major update before the expansion. If this update fixes the entirety of my issues above, I'll retract this entire review and rewrite it. If not? I'll be very depressed knowing I spent most of this year lowering my standards because of an IP I enjoy - but then I'll just go back and replay Monster Hunter Rise and World, two games I can easily run between a steam deck, laptop, and a desktop.

Don't buy the game for the full box price ($70 USD). I was able to buy it on sale at half off through a third party website and the game still has some glaring issues that make me partially regret my purchase.

1: The story

There's three types of good storytelling: have deep lore & an intricate plot (Lobotomy Corp/Mass Effect), have very little to no story (Dark Souls, the earlier monster hunter games), or have a very goofy/shitposty story (MGR:R). Neither World or Wilds fall into any of these categories and are a product of lazy writing meant to show new monsters. Limbus Company is a great example for a lot of reasons, but the encounters especially. They feel meaningful, whereas in Wilds it's a means to an end. They had each monster on a board that they'd want you to follow for progression and built the story around it instead of the other way around. So, the story very quickly disinterested me to the point I skipped (for a while, mostly parts where I KNEW people were going to be lore dumping since that's one of the worst ways to tell a story).

The main problem here is that the story is directly tied to progression (who would've guessed). If you want to ignore it, you have to put in so much effort to skip dialogue and cutscenes that it becomes a drag. So, sometimes I would watch the cutscenes again. Sometimes they're interesting, and mostly because I'm given the opportunity to piece things together myself instead of the writing team spoonfeeding me information the whole way. I only had those fun moments because I skipped the mostly lame story.

About halfway through, I decided I wanted to pay close attention to everything because I noticed just how stupid one particular character was. The wonder child, Nata, is so horribly out of touch and awfully written, I was rooting for him to lose. At one point, the Guardian Arkveld escapes and starts fucking up a LOT of the ecosystems nearby for seemingly no reason. Nata copes and acts like it never happened. "He just wanted to be free!!" With that freedom, Arkveld would later butcher, maul, and nearly eradicate an entire ecosystem in the caverns around his village. Literal chunks of flesh, bone, and sinew are being thrown around as he mutilates their corpses for pleasure. Nata's response to the order to kill him? "Nooooooo! There has to be another way! He just wanted to be free!"

Just one of many terribly written plot points in the game. There's no character development, reflection, or deep discussion from the annoying brat. Not a moment where he realizes that he placed his trust incorrectly, made assumptions about an entity he doesn't fully understand, or how the harsh realities of the world are starting to close in on him. Nope, just "NoOoOoOoOo! *sob* NOOOOOOOOOO!!" I was basically hate watching these cutscenes until the final quest finished, then I skipped everything after. If they couldn't make a good main story, I don't expect them to make a good substory anywhere else.

2: Features that should be in the game but aren't

I find there are many options for various features in the game, such as disabling damage numbers, resizing parts of the UI, controller schemes/keyboard configurations based on weapons, how your mount reacts/functions, and even some avenues to get certain lvl 1 decorations for your gear. That's just to name a few, but there are some that I would EXPECT to see, but don't. Why can't I dismiss Alma? I don't want her following me around all the time. Why can't I turn off ALL subtitles? I don't want my palico (Gods, why did they make them TALK?), Alma, or some random NPC taking up screen realestate while I'm taking in the scenery. Why can't I hide most UI elements while in combat unless I hold a key like left bumper to scroll my items? I don't need 25% of my screen being taken up by a minimap, item bar, quest objectives, and combo helper. That's not even getting into the Artian weapons. Why isn't there any sort of rerolling of the modifiers for these? Why are event quests limited timed still?

Some of these things you can fix with mods, some you can't. I have things like no subtitles, hide "recommendations" (if you play, it will CONSTANTLY show up on the right side of your screen), and a shader to make things more vibrant and disable the vignette as it washes everything out. You can't really do anything with the UI except just hide the whole thing. There's some things I want to see, like my HP, Stamina, Sharpness, but I don't need to see basically everything else.

3: Monsters

What's here is great. I won't downplay what they have because they've masterfully remastered old monsters while introducing fun and intriguing new additions. Three problems.
1, there aren't very many monsters in the total catalogue. This was an issue with World, but I gave it a pass because they were breaking into a new mold. They made so many amazing choices for the franchise in terms of looks and feel that I was willing to give them some slack. I don't really give the same credence to Wilds because they should have a better workflow by this point and should be inclined to make a better product. If you're going to jack up the price of your game to 70 USD, I'm expecting some higher quality from that extra $10.
2, it's way too easy to kill monsters. Wounds are a new mechanic introduced to the game. The clutch claw in World was an obvious problem because it warped the way the game was balanced to the point they made the Lunastra, a boss you HAD to use the clutch claw on to get a weak point to do any damage to. The clutch claw would also give you massive multipliers in the form of Weakness Exploit crits and higher weak spot damage. Wounds are similar, but spawn randomly when dealing damage to monsters. However, because of the nature of them, you're heavily encouraged to just throw your body at the monster and be highly aggressive. The more damage you do, the more wounds you get. When you break a wound, you flinch the monster and do a lot of damage. Sometimes you know them over, allowing you to push more damage, make more wounds, and repeat the cycle. You can accidentally speedrun monsters and go, "Oh, I guess it's dead now."
3, Monsters don't interact with the world or each other enough. I've seen two turf wars in total in my time playing, and one monster who changed the environment at all. The Balahara, a sandworm, is arguably the most interesting monster to fight (when it's not being stunlocked) because it can create sandpits which actively WARP the ground you're fighting on, and enable him to do unique attacks. This monster also likes walking on various pieces of terrain out of your reach so encourage you to knock it down with some slinger ammo. This is the only monster in this game that interacts in the world in any way. It's incredibly sad because this monster being shown so early hypes you up and raises your expectations. You're READY for more monsters that do stuff like this, but none come.

Perhaps this is because of time constraints (... where's that extra $10 going, CapCom?), but I did genuinely expect higher quality in the main meat of the game. It's a step up from World, sure, but it's one step.

4: (optional) Performance.

I'm pretty sure performance issues people raise stem from the extremely high demands this game has. World felt just as rich and dense zone to zone, area to area, but was able to play on significantly worse machines. I had to crank down some of the settings for Wilds which was surprising to me. I didn't think 8gb of VRAM would be barely enough to have this game run smoothly. Poor optimization is usually a sign of rushed development or negligence (where's that extra $10 going again?). I wouldn't even consider playing this game with less than 8gb of VRAM. It says you can play with 6gb on minimum settings, but I don't buy it.

I'm newer than most Monster Hunter fans. I hadn't even heard of the series before MH World released, and I didn't even seriously play it until MH World Iceborne released. Over the course of a couple years, I played MH World, and later, MH Rise extensively, leaving very little left behind to do in either title. I played both of these games with a fervor that I've not had for a game series since the early Xbox days that solidly cemented it as one of my favorite game series!

MH Wilds is not like these games. Perhaps you could argue that playing a MH game that's nearing the end of its supported lifespan is different than being there as the game is being updated, but other reviewers share a similar sentiment; Wilds has very, very little content, and has not been getting as many updates and content as fast as it should be in spite of its obviously higher budget. We are nearing a year into its lifespan, and we've seen the addition of 3 new monsters, the final boss as a replayable hunt, arch-tempered version of the apex monsters, a crossover boss, and our first Elder Dragon in the near future. 

Meanwhile... We've been getting constant paid cosmetics and problematic transactions that earlier titles also had like character edit vouchers. Between these and many reused animations from a... similarly unsuccessful game, I don't feel like it would inappropriate to say Wilds is suffering from some sort of... Dragons Dogma-fication.

Performance is still extremely terrible, and several mechanics are half baked. Some monsters will deal damage even through perfect blocks, and blocking enough attacks initiates a power clash... But only on less than half of the monsters in the game. Artian weapons are similarly poorly implemented, and are basically just the absolute best weapons in the game once you get a good roll... which is entirely RNG unless you're so bold as to install mods to let you edit the traits on your roll.

Between performance issues, lack of content, and over-correction of difficulty due to a vocal minority complaining about how easy base game was, I don't think Wilds is in a good enough place right now to be worth playing over an older title, or a different game altogether. I'd tell anyone who reads this to go play MH World or MH Rise if they haven't. Both are phenomenal games - Admittedly with their own problems, but both possess an overall more complete and enjoyable experience than MH Wilds does within a year of it's release.

The game was unfinished at launch, and after many title updates it's *still* not there. It lacks a whole bunch of features and immersion from it's predecessor (Monster Hunter World) and unlike Monster Hunter Rise, it doesn't have the excuse of being a switch game to justify it. It didn't have a hubworld, multiple features were either cut or underdeveloped, and don't go anywhere, the story ends before high rank begins (leaving a huge gap between the plot, and it's eventual continuation in the upcoming expansion.) and most importantly of all..!

The game runs horribly. Heresay doesn't do it justice, it's baffling how bad it is. It's lack of optimisation and terrible design decisions are perhaps it's most iconic traits at this point. It's built in Capcom's RE engine. An engine designed for linear, compact, and detailed worlds and environments. Capcom decided to build a massive open-world game in this engine. And add raytracing to it. Suffice to say, it didn't go well, and sales trends reflect this.

All of this is of course said with a heavy heart. This series is very dear to me, and something like this feels almost unprecedented for the Monster Hunter team. The game's story is very good for what it is, and perhaps the best the series has had so far. It's gameplay is for the most part very fun and engaging! Different to older entries, much more fast-paced and parry-heavy, like many other action games out there... But it's done very well. It's a beautiful evolution of previous ideas and mechanics that ties together into what COULD have been a definitive experience. One that blends everything they've tried for the last 10 years together.

But it just didn't make it. It falls flat on it's unfinished face. A longer dev cycle - maybe a few more months? an extra year? - could have helped, and might have even given us something serviceable. Something I'd by no means call perfect, but would absolutely have recommended. But it was built on an unstable foundation from the start. Core descisions made before they even started development doomed the game to it's unfortunate fate. It couldn't ever have been perfect under the circumstances it was created in.

And so as of the time of writing, I cannot in good faith recommend this game. I think it's wonderful ideas and potential simply aren't enough to shine through the mess of everything else about it. Monster Hunter World, many previous entries, and even Rise (for all it's own flaws) will unfortunately remain better investments of your money and time.

Amazing game, but terribly optimised. So you shouldn't buy it. I got lucky because it mostly works on my PC. Odds are it won't on your PC. And if that has changed since launch or does change in the future, you should still avoid buying it because Capcom needs to be taught a lesson or they'll do this again.

DISCLAIMER:

I only even bought the game because some friends I hadn't gamed with in a long time were trying it out, and so I knowingly took the risk of buying a broken game to spend time with them. Ironically I was the only one of us who consistently got good performance. So I'm the only one who kept playing.

But yes, I know I'm a hypocrite and part of the problem (my purchase encourages Capcom to release more broken games) by telling you not to buy this game due to poor optimisation when I knew about that poor optimisation before I bought the game. I just wanted to hear my friends' voices again.

If there's less on the line for you, then hold the line and don't buy Monster Hunter Wilds. It's what's best for all of us in the long run.

EXTENDED REVIEW:

MH Wilds' being a broken game is such a shame really, because the devs REALLY cooked and despite the smaller roster of monsters (at launch at least), I think so many other parts of Monster Hunter have been refined in Wilds.

I genuinely think that was worth launching with less monsters, since the devs have built a MUCH stronger foundation than the admittedly great one they already had from previous titles. This newly reinforced foundation will carry on to expansions and future titles (assuming they don't switch to a different engine which forces them to start from scratch).

Story (no spoilers):

The story in particular had a MASSIVE improvement. It's not perfect, but it IS good. Which was a compliment I simply could not give to MH World (I didn't finish Rise). It's not just the writing but also the way it's delivered. In World, the story felt like it intentionally did the bare minimum to get you to the next monster. MH Wilds makes each new monster feel like an obstacle you need to face to move toward a larger goal. They're either in your way, endangering someone whose help you need, or they're a crucial piece of the puzzle required to solve the mystery lying at the heart of a long dead ancient civilisation.

Gameplay:

I'd go into more detail on the gameplay itself, but while I played MH World in full, and a LITTLE bit of Rise, my knowledge on gameplay is nothing compared to that of the truly seasoned veterans of this franchise.

The early game is too easy in comparison to previous games. You will start getting challenged when Tempered monsters show up, but by then you've already beaten the final boss of the main story.

However as of 10/11/25 (10th of November for you simpleton Americans) some new VERY challenging fights have been added. Don't think it rivals my MH World PTSD yet, but they're still awesome.
